sections.title: Access Control Architecture
sections.goal: Assess the engineer's understanding of RBAC implementation, policy-as-code, and integration with enterprise SSO.
sample_questions: Explain how the current RBAC model in Aegis IAM enforces POL-SEC-001.
How does RFC-903 influence your policy-as-code deployment?
Describe the process for onboarding a new application into the SSO ecosystem.

sections.title: Incident Response & Runbooks
sections.goal: Evaluate knowledge of emergency access revocation and evidence collection.
sample_questions: Walk me through RB-IAM-075 and how it aligns with our SLA obligations.
What are the key indicators you monitor to trigger emergency revocation?
How do you ensure auditability during a high-pressure incident?

sections.title: Cross-Project Security Dependencies
sections.goal: Explore how IAM security posture impacts or is impacted by other projects like Orion Edge Gateway or Poseidon Networking.
sample_questions: Identify a scenario where a misconfiguration in Poseidon Networking could bypass IAM controls.
How would you coordinate with the Orion Edge Gateway team to enforce mTLS at both layers?
What blast radius considerations do you apply when IAM tokens are compromised?

sections.title: Risk Assessment & Trade-offs
sections.goal: Understand the interviewee's approach to balancing security with usability and operational overhead.
sample_questions: Describe a trade-off you made between strict least privilege and user productivity.
How do you justify exceptions to POL-SEC-001 during urgent production fixes?
Given conflicting SLAs between IAM and dependent services, how do you prioritize remediation?

sections.title: Evidence & Continuous Improvement
sections.goal: Check for familiarity with audits, post-incident reviews, and integrating lessons learned into the IAM platform.
sample_questions: How did AUD-24-Q2 findings influence your access review cadence?
What metrics or KPIs do you track post-incident to validate improvements?
Describe how you feed vulnerability management outcomes back into IAM hardening.
